ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course has mainly provided me with the skills to identify power and the knowledge on how interest groups manipulate the most innocent and malleable institutions for their interests.

I learned a lot about US history and the history of education. I learned theories about the functions of education, theories about how education has helped rulers to rule and expand, and examples of these theories in history. I gained insight into what education truly is.

Knowledge, in particular, is that I learnt education--besides its well-known objective to enlighten people, might also be utilized as a tool of colonial desires. I have been highly encouraged to be engaged within the class discussion.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This class was very engaging which triggered me to demand a more encompassing approach to the various themes that could occur in education under the context of an empire and imperialism, thus I wish the hefty readings could be diversified to cover more different themes and approaches which pique the question, "is the class itself a form of imperialism?".

The main strength of the class is its form of discussion-centered. Although, in my view, the instructor could prepare a mini-lecture or so and sent before class as the guidance for the students to comprehend the materials better.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, only to those who are willing to be aware of power and allow the uncertainties remain as uncertainties and not problems to be solved.

Yes. This is the first course I have taken that truly gave me an insight, which is a feeling that I can't explain. This course provided me with something that I am super eager to learn and I have experienced similar feelings before but never to this extent. I would strongly recommend this course to other students interested in education studies, history, and sociology.

Yes. This class is very interesting, especially for those who want to engage in education studies. Besides, as foreigner, I personally learnt many parts of American history which assist myself in understanding the country better.

narratives.question_text: The Canvas course site allowed me to identify and access required course materials easily.
How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: This course has helped me become aware when personally interacting with people as individuals, analyzing their true interests and how they attempt to exert power through influence.

This course helped me build a structure of knowledge for my future study and research since what I am interested in is the history of education. This course also let me know a bit about what major I want to study at the university. What is most important, this course has gave me this desire to study more, more and more!
The understandings I got from this course will be developed into further research and contextualized according to my home country.

extras.title: AFAM S259 01/AMST S253 01/EDST S250 01 - Education and Empire
